Award.AwardTitle: CDI-Type II: Collaborative Research: Computing Supermassive Black Hole Mergers in Astrophysics
Award.AbstractNarration:
Super-massive black hole mergers are believed to happen with significant frequency, but direct detection through gravitational wave observations remains only a hope for the future. An alternate path toward finding them lies through photon observations of their effects on nearby gas, but little is known for certain about what sorts of light might be produced. To solve this problem, this project is a systematic theoretical study of the electromagnetic output from these events, from the precursor stage of binary black holes, through the event itself, and including the post-merger relaxation phase. Because the quantity and character of the light radiated depends in a fundamental way on how much mass is brought to a given distance from the black holes, coordination between the initial evolution of the system, when the binary separation is large and Newtonian dynamics applies, and the merger itself, when general relativity controls the system, is an essential part of the plan. By enabling conventional telescopic observation of these systems, the aim is to create an entirely new subfield - the astronomy of black hole mergers.

These science goals can be reached only by the construction of a highly-sophisticated computational system. High-performance computation is essential because tracking the dynamics of these events involves simultaneously solving the equations of radiation transport and magneto-hydrodynamics (MHD) in a general relativistic spacetime, as well as the highly nonlinear Einstein Field Equations. Data communication requirements are also extremely challenging because even defining the dynamical spacetime of a black hole merger can require as much as several petabytes. This effort is therefore strongly multidisciplinary because of the multiple kinds of expertise needed: numerical relativity, MHD simulation, data compression, 3-d visualization, and observational astronomy.

This project will have significant additional impact, ranging from training graduate students and post-doctoral fellows in a brand-new interdisciplinary field (fluid motion in dynamical spacetime) to a variety of public outreach efforts. The junior researchers will need to learn advanced computational techniques, including parallel computing, the use of very large data sets, and scientific visualization. Public education efforts will include conventional presentations, the use of simulation animations in multi-media educational programs, and integration of simulation animations into music and dance. The necessary computational developments, such as the planned aggressive data compression procedure, will be of great value to scientists in other fields exploring ever larger dynamical systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Last fall, the most important physics discovery of the last half-century was uncovered when scientists working at the Laser Interferometer Gravitational-Wave Observatory (LIGO) first detected gravitational waves from the merger of a stellar-mass binary black holes. However, current gravitational wave detectors cannot observe the merger of supermassive black holes.

Fortunately, unlike stellar mass black hole mergers, supermassive black hole binaries are likely to be surrounded by significant quantities of gas because they follow galaxy mergers, whose dynamical relaxation pushes sizable quantities of matter toward the center of the new system. Therefore we expect these systems to be very bright; emitting copious amounts of electromagnetic radiation from radio waves all the way up through gamma rays. Our project aims was to provide the community with predictions of these electromagnetic signatures using realistic conditions that arise from galaxy mergers.

To make our work feasible within the limits of contemporary computational resources, we invented a new simulation infrastructure that provides enough computational cells to resolve magnetohydrodynamics turbulence in the circumbinary accretion disk with sufficient duration to understand secular trends, and to follow the shock waves and nonlinear spacetime dynamics taking place near each black hole. Applying this framework to calculations whose parameters are chosen to be astrophysically plausible, we discovered a number of generic features that completely overturned the earlier understanding of these systems.  Previous work based on low-dimensional hydrodynamical simulation had argued that no gas could flow from the disk to the binary when the black hole masses are near to unity, due to tidal torques exerted by the binary onto the gas. Our 3-D magnetohydrodynamics simulations ran long enough to allow the binary to shrink down close the merger, showing no substantial change in the accretion rate from the circumbinary disk onto the binary. We also discovered that streams of gas are peeled off from the inner edge of the circumbinary disk, and fall into the central region, which are expected to cause shocks against the outer edges of the individual black hole minidisks. We also find that gas is liberated from each black hole minidisks (“sloshing”), continually passes back and forth from the domain dominated by one black hole to that dominated by the other black hole and back again, shocking against the outer edge of the minidisks at each passage. Additionally, we found spiral waves in the minidisks, also found in other Newtonian studies, but taking an entirely new symmetry due to relativistic effects. This sloshing and spiral waves have the potential to create distinctive radiation features that may uniquely mark supermassive binary black holes in the relativistic regime. We find distinctive radiation features that may uniquely mark supermassive binary black holes in the relativistic regime.

During this project 4 post-doctoral fellows, 3 graduate students and several undergraduate student were trained in the techniques of large-scale numerical simulation and new multipatch hydrodynamics infrastructure was developed. They learned many skills easily transferable to an extremely wide range of other applications in diverse areas of science and even in the commercial world: how to choose simulation parameters for maximum interpretability, how to design new algorithms for numerical problems, how to optimize codes for parallel computing, how to manage---and understand---massive data outputs. These skills and codes are valuable far beyond the confines of astrophysical research; former students and post-docs now use them in areas as diverse as harbor design and global climate modeling.

This grant also provided data for scientific visualizations for a novel performance, known as Astrodance, designed at engaging deaf students in astrophysics using innovative animations and artistic performances.  Participants on this grant were part of several film productions that promotes gravitational wave research and the study of black hole astrophysics. These short films were distributed in the social media and uploaded in YouTube.  Finally, our research products are also used in exhibits seen by tens of thousands of people during the annual "ImagineRIT" festival, which attracts over 30,000 visitors (including many children).
